case_vignette: A 63-year-old man comes to the physician for the evaluation of a skin lesion on his chest. He first noticed the lesion 2 months ago and thinks that it has increased in size since then. The lesion is not painful or pruritic. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypercholesterolemia, and glaucoma. The patient has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for the last 40 years and drinks two to three beers on the weekend. Current medications include metformin, atorvastatin, topical timolol, and a multivitamin. Vital signs are within normal limits. The lesion is partly elevated on palpation and does not change its form on pinching. A photograph of the lesion is shown.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I came in because of a spot on my chest that's been growing over the past two months.

Great, thank you for letting me know. Can you tell me more about the spot on your chest? What does it look like? Is it changing in size or shape? And have you noticed any other symptoms such as redness, swelling, or discharge?

The spot on my chest isn't painful or itchy, but it has gotten bigger since I first saw it. It stays the same shape when I pinch it and feels a bit raised when I touch it. No redness, swelling, or discharge.

Thank you for providing more information. Based on what you've told me, it's possible that the spot on your chest could be a benign skin growth, such as a sebaceous hyperplasia or a keratosis. These types of growths are usually slow-growing and non-cancerous, but it's always best to have them checked by a dermatologist to rule out any potential skin cancers.

Can you tell me more about your medical history? Have you had any previous skin cancers or precancerous lesions? Have you noticed any other unusual changes in your skin?
I have type 2 diabetes, high cholesterol, and glaucoma, but no history of skin cancer or precancerous lesions. No other unusual skin changes that I've noticed.

Thank you for letting me know. Based on your medical history and the symptoms you've described, it's possible that the spot on your chest could be a benign skin growth, but it's also possible that it could be related to your underlying medical conditions.

I would recommend scheduling an appointment with a dermatologist for a thorough evaluation of the spot on your chest. They will be able to examine the spot and perform any necessary tests to determine the cause and recommend appropriate treatment.

In the meantime, it's important to keep an eye on the spot and monitor it for any changes in size, shape, or color. If you notice any significant changes or if you experience any discomfort or pain, be sure to contact your dermatologist right away.

Remember, it's always better to be safe than sorry when it comes to your health, so don't hesitate to seek medical attention if you have any concerns.

**Final Diagnosis:** Benign skin growth or sebaceous hyperplasia.
